item.title: I write to find out what I think
item.description: The other day, I remembered my high school math teacher and how combinatorics was one of the few topics I was interested in. Somehow, it seemed to delight me being able to envision an universe of possibilities within a given circumstance. This morning, I ended up putting that memory together with an idea that has been inhabiting me lately: that of writing as an exercise of reflection and discovery. Lessons that never end…

Combinatorial analysis exercise I

I write to discover what I think.
I think to write what I discover.
I discover to think what I write.
I write to think what I discover.
I think to discover what I write.
I discover to write what I think.

item.title: Party of the bothered ones
item.description: A bothered person talks about some annoyance. Some bothered ones agree, other bothered ones disagree. At the party, those who aren't bothered are divided into two groups of people who are bothered: those who aren't bothered by that annoyance, but by the fact that there are so many bothered people bothering them; and those who aren't bothered by absolutely nothing, with the exception of those who aren't bothered by being bothered by so many bothers, which, it's known, causes them a deep annoyance.
item.content:
A bothered person talks about some annoyance. Some bothered ones agree, other bothered ones disagree. At the party, those who aren't bothered are divided into two groups of people who are bothered: those who aren't bothered by that annoyance, but by the fact that there are so many bothered people bothering them; and those who aren't bothered by absolutely nothing, with the exception of those who aren't bothered by being bothered by so many bothers, which, it's known, causes them a deep annoyance.

In the end, the only ones who decided not to go to the party weren't bothered – which certainly bothered a lot of people. I mean, that's how it seemed… at least until they realized they weren't even invited.
